reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Standard reference for the Analects
reviews.reviewText: This should really be considered THE standard reference for the Analects in English. Slingerland's linguistic choices, in terms of which word to use for a specific Chinese character, are impeccable.Downsides: It doesn't adhere to a single traditional Chinese interpretation, notably the Zhu Xi interpretation that has been dominant for over 600 years. Although it features commentary, which is excellently translated, the selections appear to be subjectively chosen without a consistent standard. Furthermore, the phraseology of the translations leans more toward a verbose Western style and narrow logic, as opposed to the "concise yet open" gu-wen 古文 style in which the Analects is written.That said, as a comprehensive "reference standard," there's really no other work that compares.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best Translation of the Analects
reviews.reviewText: If I recommend that a friend read The Analects, I specifically single out this translation as the go-to. The phrasing is brilliant, succinct, and easily digestible. The author has expertly selected relevant commentaries to include and editorializes in a nuanced manner that emphasizes the fluid and subjective nature of interpreting these ancient ideas.The author treats the reader with respect by not shying away from uncertainty yet makes these complex and nuanced topics easy to understand by a modern audience.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Greatly helpful commentaries
reviews.reviewText: There's at least a few sentences of exposition for each saying or dialogue, and some expositions last for a page. Slingerland's selections from traditional commentaries help to explain the more semiotically embedded analects: for example, the obscure conversation in 4.21 about a chestnut tree is illuminated by the knowledge that "chestnut tree" is a classical Chinese pun on "fear," which has the same character and pronunciation. This edition is especially helpful for outsiders like me.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I am not a student of Eastern religion or philosophy. When I had to take such a class, I used this translation at the suggestion of my professor. I appreciated the translation and the explanations in between all of the passages, which made this portion of my class much more easily grasped.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2012
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Only get this version
reviews.reviewText: Honestly, don't get any other copy of the Analects. Due to the nature of the Analects, which are composed of short passages and proverbs, a straight reading of them in English can leave one underwhelmed. The Analects are brought to life when one acquires the historical and philosophical context that sheds light on its passages. In other words, the Analects only actually make sense (the way they're supposed to) with the commentaries. As far as I know, this is the only English translation in print with some of these commentaries. Reading the Analects with the commentaries totally changed my understanding of Confucianism.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2014
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Above average, but confusing at times
reviews.reviewText: Slingerland's translation of the Analects is not bad. However, I am only giving it three stars. This is because there are some points where the author purposefully diverges from what he knows to be the normal understanding of a sentence. For example, verse 3.23 inverts the meaning of the sentence, making Confucius an Aristotelian. In verse 9.1 the remarkable statement that "Confucius rarely spoke about goodness", known to all Chinese, is turned on its head through a revisionist reading of a character. The latter translation is explained at length in commentary, so that the reader is aware what is going on, but the former is not.Before you buy, go to a large public library and try comparing this to an edition by Burton Watson or Arthur Waley.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Probably the best contemporary translation of the Analects.
reviews.reviewText: I teach Chinese Philosophy. Although I do not read Classical Chinese and can't comment on the quality of the translation from that perspective, I will say the text is very fluent and the translator is well-respected. This translation is frequently cited by other experts. The commentary is excellent. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2015
reviews.reviewText: I can't wait to start reading this! I'm fascinated with Chinese philosophy. I do not believe in western "religions", however, I like to surround myself more with East Asian "practices" that have a beautiful basis of harmony. I didn't think a book like this was available (even living in this generation) but I'm happy to have discovered it. The cover blows my mind with anticipation!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 15, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: Great edition with excellent introduction and contextual information throughout
reviews.reviewText: This edition of the Analects translated by Edward Slingerland has a clear and erudite introduction to engage the non scholar and each book has accompanying information to contextualise and give meaning to the sayings. Very enjoyable reading.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 10, 2014
reviews.reviewText: I can't comment on the accuracy of the translation. I have, however, read a number of translations, and this was by far the clearest and most readable. The commentary was pitched perfectly, giving me the context I needed without overwhelming the text. I came away with a deeper understanding and appreciation of Confucius. This is the version I will be going back to again and again.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 19, 2016
reviews.reviewText: Shake up your thinking! You might not understand the words of the Master at first reading, but the excellent commentaries will elucidate and stimulate the mind. Interesting to find how thoughts and ideas of another time and place are similar to what are more usually found at home, today in one's own culture.
